title: Complaints vs. Criticism
description: Explore how issues are raisedâ€”behavior-focused or character-focused

questions.text: When concerns come up, I feel addressed for what I did, not who I am.

therapeutic.rationale: Complaints address behavior ('I felt hurt when...'); criticism attacks character ('You're so selfish'). The difference determines whether partners feel correctable or condemned.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner experiences character attacks, specific examples help. The other partner may not realize they've crossed from complaint to criticism.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual focus on issues rather than character keeps conflict constructive.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Does your partner tend to address issues or attack character? How about you?

questions.text: I try to address specific situations rather than making 'you always' or 'you never' statements.

therapeutic.rationale: 'Always' and 'never' statements overgeneralize and put partners on defense. Addressing specific situations keeps the conversation solvable and fair.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner uses absolutes, they may feel unheard about recurring issues. Finding other ways to communicate patterns helps.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual commitment to specifics creates accurate, productive discussions.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How often do 'always' and 'never' show up in your conflicts? What triggers them?

questions.text: I feel like a good person who made a mistake, not a bad person, when my partner raises concerns.

therapeutic.rationale: How concerns are raised determines whether you feel like a good person who erred or a fundamentally flawed person. The former invites growth; the latter invites shame.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner feels like a bad person, explore what creates that feeling. Is it the words used? Tone? Or their own shame sensitivity? Both factors can be addressed.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual experience of being treated as good people creates safety for growth.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: After your partner raises a concern, do you feel correctable or condemned?

questions.text: Our disagreements focus on solving problems, not proving who's worse.

therapeutic.rationale: Conflicts that become about who's the bigger problem miss the point. Focusing on solving the issue rather than establishing fault creates teamwork.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If conflicts become about who's worse, notice when the shift happens. Redirecting back to the issue at hand keeps things productive.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared focus on problem-solving rather than blame creates effective conflict.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do your conflicts focus on solving problems or determining who's wrong?

questions.text: I can separate what my partner did from who they are.

therapeutic.rationale: Separating behavior from identity allows you to be upset about something your partner did while still loving who they are. Conflating the two creates relationship-threatening conflicts.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner struggles to separate behavior from identity, explore what triggers the conflation. Hurt often makes us see patterns as character.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual ability to separate actions from identity protects the relationship during conflict.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When you're upset with your partner, can you still see them as a good person?
